commentary.line: So, that's all we have for you from this game. Many thanks for your company. Tomorrow there's a double-header coming your way, first up it will be Pakistan vs UAE and the second game is between Australia and Afghanistan. So don't forget to follow the action right here. Until next time and on behalf of Sriram, Raju, Krishna, my co-commentators, Akshay, Ramakrishnan and Pradeep, this is Sidhant Maheshwari signing off. Take care folks! See you tomorrow.
@cricketaakash: There should be a rule that doesn't allow SA to bat first...400 is the new 250 for them while batting first.
@BrokenCricket: 400 is New 350 300 is New 250 Double Century is New 150 150 is New Century.. But England & Pakistan Still lives in Stone Age
@mohanstatsman: Last three of South Africa's 400+ totals have come in just 44 days!
@rgcricket: Only the second time in ODIs a side has won two consecutive matches by a margin of 200 runs. Australia did so in 2007
@cricketaakash: Fastest to 5000 ODI runs, fastest to 20 ODI centuries...from someone who isn't even considered an ODI superstar. Hashim Amla take a bow!
Let's have a look at some of the tweets from this game:

de Villiers: 'It was a good game today. I am very happy with the performance. The nice thing about the batting display today was especially the fact that we did it our way. We are not following anyone else's strategy. We followed our game plans and guys played exceptionally well upfront. It set it up nicely for the rest in the middle-order. There's been a lot of hundreds over the last 12-18 months and it's something we are very proud of. When they keep scoring centuries, we feel that it definitely helps in setting it up for the latter stages of the innings. Very proud of the way Hash (Hashim Amla) and Faf (Faf du Plessis) played today, exceptional partnership and that set it up nicely for us. Incredible, still the rock (talking about Amla) and he will always be the rock for us. He does this effortlessly, plays with a lot of class and his game plans are so set that whatever you do, he has always got an answer, it seems like it. Hopefully, his form can continue for the rest of the tour. Very much pleased will all the bowlers, we had a nice meeting yesterday chatting about how we are going to go about the rest of the tournament. The guys were very motivated for today, wanting to do well, wanted to pick up wickets and stay positive right throughout the innings. I saw every single bit of that today. It is very much a match-to-match basis decision (talking about who to play at No. 7). I am very comfortable with whatever balance we create and as long as I am comfortable and the team follows, everything will be alright. You always want your top 6-7 in good form, especially, I would say 6, 7, 8 win you a lot of pressure games in tournaments like this and they seem to be in really good form as well. Everyone that's got an opportunity throughout this tournament seems to have done well. So, just a bit more of that and hopefully, we will do well in the next one as well. We will see how we go (asked if he will bowl again in the next game), I go on my instinct. I very much did (asked if he enjoyed when the umpire told him one bouncer for the over), that was actually my slower bouncer and I very much enjoyed it.'

Porterfield: 'It was a difficult evening. Obviously, they came out and played very well. We got one early breakthrough and we would have liked a couple more, but once the lads got set on that deck, it was hard to claw back. You want to be taking your chances, but that's part of cricket as well and you have to move on from that (talking about the dropped catch of Amla when he was on 10). All credit to him, he played very well, but, it is just one of those things. It was obviously a very good pitch and it was difficult to try and muster up those wickets. But the lads tried to squeeze as much as they could in the middle and put some kind of pressure on. We slowed them down a bit coming down at the last 10 with a couple of wickets, but we would have liked a few more earlier on. We were 4 down coming down after 10 and they bowled pretty well, if you're 4 down after 10 chasing any score, you're going to struggle, but all credit to the lower order where they stuck at it and fought it out there. Every game is a big game and obviously the game against Zimbabwe is a big game for us. So, we are looking to pick up 2 points.'

Hashim Amla: 'Fortunately, we got off to a good start. Myself and Faf just got something going and then we started playing a few shots. We had wickets in hand, so we kind of had the luxury to do that. We just thought that let's have a go and see what happens and thankfully it came off. And we have got a good batting line-up to come, they weren't really needed today, but that's why it gave us time to do it at the top. The guys have been batting well, it was a good wicket and fortunately, we got some runs today. We don't look too far ahead, it is always nice to win a game of cricket. No matter who you're playing against, we are just grateful that we managed to go over the line today. Any hundred is a hundred (when asked about how much it matters to be the fastest to 20 ODI tons), I am just glad to get some runs. It doesn't matter how long it takes, but I am just glad to be getting some runs upfront, setting it up for the boys at the back end and those guys are quite dangerous there. They bowled exceptionally well, I was just glad that the one that flicked Quinny's (Quinton de Kock) glove, didn't hit me in my teeth. Amazingly, it got stuck under my armpit. The guys bowled exceptionally well. Having a team four down chasing 400, the writing was almost on the wall. But they maintained their good intensity throughout the game and fortunately, we walked away with a comfortable victory.'
Hashim Amla is the Man of the Match for his 159

Earlier in the day, Amla and Faf du Plessis put on a record 2nd wicket partnership to help South Africa post their second successive 400-plus score on the board. Rossouw and Miller too made useful contributions towards the back end of the innings. But, it was Amla and Faf, who stole the show with marvellous hundreds. Overall, it was a thorough performance from the Proteas.

It was a clinical display by the South African bowlers. Steyn was back to his fiery best and Abbott has made the most of the opportunities he has been given. Morkel kept it tight at one end but Tahir was a bit inconsistent today. ABD tried a few different options in Faf, Rossouw and himself. He also managed to pick up a wicket in his very first over.

However, Balbirnie departed soon after reaching his maiden ODI fifty. Kevin O'Brien, who had played the waiting game until the batting powerplay, fell off the very first delivery of the powerplay. Dockrell and Sorensen prolonged the inevitable for a while. The pair added 31 runs for the 9th wicket before Morne came back and finished things off.

It is a comprehensive win for South Africa, their second on the trot. Ireland's run-chase never got going. Porterfield and Stirling played some delightful shots, but Steyn and Abbott sent them back in quick succession. Ed Joyce followed soon after. At one stage, they were reeling at 48/5 before Balbirnie and Kevin O'Brien added 81 runs for the sixth wicket. It was Ireland's highest partnership against South Africa for any wicket.

Drinks are on the field now. It is only a matter of time before South Africa wrap it up. Things could have been worse for the Irish had O'Brien and Balbirnie not combined for a 81-run partnership. However, let's see how they go about now. Abbott has taken 4 wickets in the innings and he will look to finish with a 5-wicket haul.

It goes towards deep mid-wicket and the fielder there takes an easy catch. Ireland are 8 down now. K O'Brien c Rossouw b Kyle Abbott 48(65) [4s-3 6s-1]

Morne has been economical at one end. These two have to get Ireland to a respectable score, else it will be an embarrassing defeat.

Welcome back.. Ireland have chased down targets of over 280 in their previous two matches. But, this is 400-plus and a more accomplished bowling attack. Can they get anywhere close to this target? We'll find out soon as Steyn steams in.

Faf: "We did the basics really well again today and that's what we want to do as a top order. We want to lay the foundation for the guys at the end to have some fun. So, once again, really proud of the boys. It was nice (to bat), obviously hard work up front to get us into position and then when you do get into position, you try and have some fun as well. So nice to do it with Hash (Amla) today. It (pitch) looked a little bit better today and especially, we know as a batting unit we've got some really big power-hitters. Obviously Ireland, from a bowling point of view at the death, not very experienced. So we knew if we get into position to dominate, we could hurt them. Luckily today, it came off. It's great to bat with Hash (Amla), he's such an experienced guy, the best thing about him is the coversion rate. When he gets to 50, so many times he gets to 100. So for guys like myself, it's good to learn from that and then try and be half as good as that."

For Ireland, Mooney started the proceedings on a good note. In his first 5 overs, he picked up a wicket and just gave away 9 runs. However, during the final stages of the innings, he was smashed all around and went for 43 off just 2 overs in his second spell. George Dockrell was the only bowler, who gave away less than 6 runs an over. Apart from him, the South Africans took a toll of the other bowlers, especially Sorensen and Kevin O'Brien. Sorensen gave away 76 in his 6 and O'Brien also conceded 95 runs in his 7 overs as well. It is going to be extremely difficult for Ireland to chase this down. But, we have seen funnier things happen in cricket. Join us in a short while to follow the run-chase.

du Plessis was deceived by a yorker from Kevin O'Brien and de Villiers came out to bat after him. He started off in his usual manner, racing away to 22 off just 7 balls. However, Andy McBrine sent both Amla and de Villiers back in a space of 3 balls to halt the South African onslaught. After that Miller and Rossouw took the onus of going after the bowling. Both of them thrashed the Irish bowlers to all parts of the park and helped their team go past 400, becoming the first team to score 400 in consecutive games. Both of them finished unbeaten, with Rossouw bringing up his 3rd ODI fifty just before the end of the innings as South Africa recorded the second highest score in World Cup history.

South Africa didn't get off to the best of starts, with de Kock failing one more time. Ever since he has come back from injury, he has struggled to get going with the bat. However, like the last game, Hashim Amla and Faf du Plessis got together and steadied the ship from there on. Their rotation of strike was great and they made sure that the Irish couldn't bog them down, dispatching the loose ones to the fence. Both of them were together from the 3rd over till the 39th and put on 247 runs for the second wicket. In the process, Hashim Amla (108 innings) became the fastest man to reach 20 ODI hundreds, going past Virat Kohli. du Plessis also soon reached his ton and both of them then tried to accelerate.

Drinks are on the field now. This brilliant double-hundred stand has put South Africa in a great position. Ireland will have to bowl really well from here on to be chasing anything less than 375. The stage is set for the likes of de Villiers, Rossouw and Miller. Can they score 400 again? We'll find out in a while.

23.1   Sorensen to Amla, SIX, lovely shot, this was a length ball and just outside off, Amla shuffles across, gets underneath the length and hoicks it high and over wide long-on for a maximum
